let's move on to the next thing which is health checks health checks is a very
common concern inside applications that are hosted in production that have lots
of dependencies where you want to ensure that that application can report its status and potentially have an
Orchestrator of some type either not send traffic to that application what a
reboot it if something is wrong automatically okay so the health checks API is now in a
snit core to help you with that problem health checks can pass or fail it's pretty straightforward but the pass I'll
the failure can be mapped to one of three states your health check and say your application is healthy you can say
the health of the application has in a degraded state which means whatever it means for that application or I can say
that the application is unhealthy that's really important because that plugs into the idea of both liveness and readiness
checks and if you've ever used something like kubernetes this will be very little be all too obvious to you you want to
understand that your application is alive meaning it's not dead it is alive and it's running well give me traffic all right but then
there's readiness which is I'm okay but just don't send me traffic right now you don't need to reboot me all right but
just don't give me traffic right now and that's useful if the application is starting up and priming its caches or maybe it's gone through a burst of load
and it just likes you to back off for a moment while I catches up that's the readiness check liveness is
like I can't talk to my database my hard drive is full I'm gonna stack overflow or something that process would have
crashed identity but something else okay and then you just knew you're you're basically indicating to someone I'm done
right I'm over you need to come and reboot me alright we've included a simple middleware that lets you expose
